cells.data:
Midterm review

$32^7 \mod 11$
$32 \equiv (-1) \mod 11$
$32^7 \equiv (-1)^7 \equiv -1 \mod 11$

$a = qd + r$
$0 \leq r \lt d$
$a \mod m := r$
$a \div m := q$

Euclidean $\gcd$ algorithm
Continue to divide with remainder; last non-zero remainder is the $\gcd$
Then we can write it as a linear combination

Linear congruences
Suppose $\gcd(a,n) = 1$
$ax \equiv b \mod n$
$x$ is unique $\mod n$
We solve by finding $a'$ such that $aa' \equiv 1 \mod n$
OR
We write $ai + nj = 1$ using Euclidean algorithm
Then $ai \equiv 1 \mod n$ and
$a(bi) \equiv b \mod n$ and 
$x \equiv bi \mod n$

No CRT on exam

Induction (weak, strong)

Relations

Counting
